trans-unit.source: Linux tutorial: Get started with Hadoop and Hive | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Linux tutorial: Get started with Hadoop and Hive | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Follow this Linux tutorial to get started using Hadoop in HDInsight. Learn how to provision Linux clusters, and query data with Hive.
trans-unit.target: Follow this Linux tutorial to get started using Hadoop in HDInsight. Learn how to provision Linux clusters, and query data with Hive.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop tutorial: Get started using Hadoop with Hive in HDInsight on Linux (preview)
trans-unit.target: Hadoop tutorial: Get started using Hadoop with Hive in HDInsight on Linux (preview)

trans-unit.source: This Hadoop tutorial gets you started quickly with Azure HDInsight on Linux by showing you how to provision an Hadoop cluster on Linux and run a Hive query.
trans-unit.target: This Hadoop tutorial gets you started quickly with Azure HDInsight on Linux by showing you how to provision an Hadoop cluster on Linux and run a Hive query.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Hadoop and big data, you can read more about the terms <html></html>Apache Hadoop<html></html>, <html></html>MapReduce<html></html>, <html></html>Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)<html></html>, and <html></html>Hive<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Hadoop and big data, you can read more about the terms <html></html>Apache Hadoop<html></html>, <html></html>MapReduce<html></html>, <html></html>Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)<html></html>, and <html></html>Hive<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: To understand how HDInsight enables Hadoop in Azure, see <link><linkText>Introduction to Hadoop in HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To understand how HDInsight enables Hadoop in Azure, see <link><linkText>Introduction to Hadoop in HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: What does this tutorial accomplish?
trans-unit.target: What does this tutorial accomplish?

trans-unit.source: Assume you have a large unstructured data set and you want to run queries on it to extract some meaningful information.
trans-unit.target: Assume you have a large unstructured data set and you want to run queries on it to extract some meaningful information.

trans-unit.source: Here's how you achieve this:
trans-unit.target: Here's how you achieve this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hadoop tutorial steps: Create a Storage account; provision a Hadoop cluster; query data with Hive.</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hadoop tutorial steps: Create a Storage account; provision a Hadoop cluster; query data with Hive.</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this Linux tutorial for Hadoop, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this Linux tutorial for Hadoop, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Secure Shell (SSH) keys.
trans-unit.target: Secure Shell (SSH) keys.

trans-unit.source: If you want to remote into a Linux cluster by using SSH with a key instead of a password.
trans-unit.target: If you want to remote into a Linux cluster by using SSH with a key instead of a password.

trans-unit.source: Using a key is the recommended method as it is more secure.
trans-unit.target: Using a key is the recommended method as it is more secure.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to generate SSH keys, refer to the following articles:
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to generate SSH keys, refer to the following articles:

trans-unit.source: From a Linux computer - <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: From a Linux computer - <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: From a Windows computer - <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: From a Windows computer - <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Estimated time to complete: 30 minutes
trans-unit.target: Estimated time to complete: 30 minutes

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Provision an HDInsight cluster on Linux
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Provision an HDInsight cluster on Linux

trans-unit.source: When you provision a cluster, you provision Azure compute resources that contain Hadoop and related applications.
trans-unit.target: When you provision a cluster, you provision Azure compute resources that contain Hadoop and related applications.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you provision an HDInsight version 3.2 cluster.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you provision an HDInsight version 3.2 cluster.

trans-unit.source: You can also create Hadoop clusters for other versions.
trans-unit.target: You can also create Hadoop clusters for other versions.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters using custom options[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters using custom options[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For information about HDInsight versions and their SLAs, see <link><linkText>HDInsight component versioning</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about HDInsight versions and their SLAs, see <link><linkText>HDInsight component versioning</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can also create Hadoop clusters running the Windows Server operating system.
trans-unit.target: You can also create Hadoop clusters running the Windows Server operating system.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Get Started with HDInsight on Windows</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Get Started with HDInsight on Windows</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To provision an HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: To provision an HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click NEW, Click Data Analytics, and then click HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Click NEW, Click Data Analytics, and then click HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating a new cluster in the Azure Preview Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating a new cluster in the Azure Preview Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter a Cluster Name, select Hadoop for the Cluster Type, and from the Cluster Operating System drop-down, select Ubuntu.
trans-unit.target: Enter a Cluster Name, select Hadoop for the Cluster Type, and from the Cluster Operating System drop-down, select Ubuntu.

trans-unit.source: A green check will appear beside the cluster name if it is available.
trans-unit.target: A green check will appear beside the cluster name if it is available.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Enter cluster name and type</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Enter cluster name and type</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, click the Subscription entry to select the Azure subscription that will be used for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, click the Subscription entry to select the Azure subscription that will be used for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Click Resource Group to see a list of existing resource groups and then select the one to create the cluster in.
trans-unit.target: Click Resource Group to see a list of existing resource groups and then select the one to create the cluster in.

trans-unit.source: Or, you can click Create New and then enter the name of the new resource group.
trans-unit.target: Or, you can click Create New and then enter the name of the new resource group.

trans-unit.source: A green check will appear to indicate if the new group name is available.
trans-unit.target: A green check will appear to indicate if the new group name is available.

trans-unit.source: This entry will default to one of your existing resource groups, if any are available.
trans-unit.target: This entry will default to one of your existing resource groups, if any are available.

trans-unit.source: Click Credentials and then enter a password for the admin user.
trans-unit.target: Click Credentials and then enter a password for the admin user.

trans-unit.source: You must also enter an SSH Username and either a PASSWORD or PUBLIC KEY, which will be used to authenticate the SSH user.
trans-unit.target: You must also enter an SSH Username and either a PASSWORD or PUBLIC KEY, which will be used to authenticate the SSH user.

trans-unit.source: Using a public key is the recommended approach.
trans-unit.target: Using a public key is the recommended approach.

trans-unit.source: Click Select at the bottom to save the credentials configuration.
trans-unit.target: Click Select at the bottom to save the credentials configuration.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Provide cluster credentials</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Provide cluster credentials</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For more information on using SSH with HDInsight, see one of the following articles:
trans-unit.target: For more information on using SSH with HDInsight, see one of the following articles:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Click Data Source to choose an existing data source for the cluster, or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Click Data Source to choose an existing data source for the cluster, or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: When you provision a Hadoop cluster in HDInsight, you specify an Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: When you provision a Hadoop cluster in HDInsight, you specify an Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: A specific Blob storage container from that account is designated as the default file system, like in the Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS).
trans-unit.target: A specific Blob storage container from that account is designated as the default file system, like in the Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS).

trans-unit.source: By default, the HDInsight cluster is provisioned in the same data center as the storage account you specify.
trans-unit.target: By default, the HDInsight cluster is provisioned in the same data center as the storage account you specify.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data source blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data source blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Currently you can select an Azure Storage Account as the data source for an HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Currently you can select an Azure Storage Account as the data source for an HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Use the following to understand the entries on the Data Source blade.
trans-unit.target: Use the following to understand the entries on the Data Source blade.

trans-unit.source: Selection Method: Set this to From all subscriptions to enable browsing of storage accounts from all your subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Selection Method: Set this to From all subscriptions to enable browsing of storage accounts from all your subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Set this to Access Key if you want to enter the Storage Name and Access Key of an existing storage account.
trans-unit.target: Set this to Access Key if you want to enter the Storage Name and Access Key of an existing storage account.

trans-unit.source: Select storage account / Create New: Click Select storage account to browse and select an existing storage account you want to associate with the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Select storage account / Create New: Click Select storage account to browse and select an existing storage account you want to associate with the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Or, click Create New to create a new storage account.
trans-unit.target: Or, click Create New to create a new storage account.

trans-unit.source: Use the field that appears to enter the name of the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Use the field that appears to enter the name of the storage account.

trans-unit.source: A green check will appear if the name is available.
trans-unit.target: A green check will appear if the name is available.

trans-unit.source: Choose Default Container: Use this to enter the name of the default container to use for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Choose Default Container: Use this to enter the name of the default container to use for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: While you can enter any name here, we recommend using the same name as the cluster so that you can easily recognize that the container is used for this specific cluster.
trans-unit.target: While you can enter any name here, we recommend using the same name as the cluster so that you can easily recognize that the container is used for this specific cluster.

trans-unit.source: Location: The geographic region that the storage account is in, or will be created in.
trans-unit.target: Location: The geographic region that the storage account is in, or will be created in.

trans-unit.source: Selecting the location for the default data source will also set the location of the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Selecting the location for the default data source will also set the location of the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: The cluster and default data source must be located in the same region.
trans-unit.target: The cluster and default data source must be located in the same region.

trans-unit.source: Click Select to save the data source configuration.
trans-unit.target: Click Select to save the data source configuration.

trans-unit.source: Click Node Pricing Tiers to display information about the nodes that will be created for this cluster.
trans-unit.target: Click Node Pricing Tiers to display information about the nodes that will be created for this cluster.

trans-unit.source: Set the number of worker nodes that you need for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Set the number of worker nodes that you need for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The estimated cost of the cluster will be shown within the blade.
trans-unit.target: The estimated cost of the cluster will be shown within the blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Node pricing tiers blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Node pricing tiers blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Select to save the node pricing configuration.
trans-unit.target: Click Select to save the node pricing configuration.

trans-unit.source: On the New HDInsight Cluster blade, ensure that Pin to Startboard is selected, and then click Create.
trans-unit.target: On the New HDInsight Cluster blade, ensure that Pin to Startboard is selected, and then click Create.

trans-unit.source: This will create the cluster and add a tile for it to the Startboard of your Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will create the cluster and add a tile for it to the Startboard of your Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: The icon will indicate that the cluster is provisioning, and will change to display the HDInsight icon once provisioning has completed.
trans-unit.target: The icon will indicate that the cluster is provisioning, and will change to display the HDInsight icon once provisioning has completed.

trans-unit.source: While provisioning
trans-unit.target: While provisioning

trans-unit.source: Provisioning complete
trans-unit.target: Provisioning complete

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Provisioning indicator on startboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Provisioning indicator on startboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Provisioned cluster tile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Provisioned cluster tile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: It will take some time for the cluster to be created, usually around 15 minutes.
trans-unit.target: It will take some time for the cluster to be created, usually around 15 minutes.

trans-unit.source: Use the tile on the Startboard, or the Notifications entry on the left of the page to check on the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: Use the tile on the Startboard, or the Notifications entry on the left of the page to check on the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: Once the provisioning is completed, click the tile for the cluster from the Startboard to launch the cluster blade.
trans-unit.target: Once the provisioning is completed, click the tile for the cluster from the Startboard to launch the cluster blade.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Submit a Hive job on the cluster
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Submit a Hive job on the cluster

trans-unit.source: Now that you have an HDInsight Linux cluster provisioned, the next step is to run a sample Hive job to query sample data (sample.log) that comes with HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have an HDInsight Linux cluster provisioned, the next step is to run a sample Hive job to query sample data (sample.log) that comes with HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: The sample data contains log information, including trace, warnings, info, and errors.
trans-unit.target: The sample data contains log information, including trace, warnings, info, and errors.

trans-unit.source: We query this data to retrieve all the error logs with a specific severity.
trans-unit.target: We query this data to retrieve all the error logs with a specific severity.

trans-unit.source: You must perform the following steps to run a Hive query on an HDInsight Linux cluster:
trans-unit.target: You must perform the following steps to run a Hive query on an HDInsight Linux cluster:

trans-unit.source: Connect to a Linux cluster
trans-unit.target: Connect to a Linux cluster

trans-unit.source: Run a Hive job
trans-unit.target: Run a Hive job

trans-unit.source: To connect to a cluster
trans-unit.target: To connect to a cluster

trans-unit.source: You can connect to an HDInsight cluster on Linux from a Linux computer or a Windows-based computer by using SSH.
trans-unit.target: You can connect to an HDInsight cluster on Linux from a Linux computer or a Windows-based computer by using SSH.

trans-unit.source: To connect from a Linux computer
trans-unit.target: To connect from a Linux computer

trans-unit.source: Open a terminal and enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: Open a terminal and enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: Because you provisioned a cluster with the Quick Create option, the default SSH user name is hdiuser.
trans-unit.target: Because you provisioned a cluster with the Quick Create option, the default SSH user name is hdiuser.

trans-unit.source: So, the command must be:
trans-unit.target: So, the command must be:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the password that you provided while provisioning the cluster.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the password that you provided while provisioning the cluster.

trans-unit.source: After you are successfully connected, the prompt will change to the following:
trans-unit.target: After you are successfully connected, the prompt will change to the following:

trans-unit.source: To connect from a Windows-based computer
trans-unit.target: To connect from a Windows-based computer

trans-unit.source: Download <html></html>PuTTY<html></html> for Windows-based clients.
trans-unit.target: Download <html></html>PuTTY<html></html> for Windows-based clients.

trans-unit.source: Open PuTTY.
trans-unit.target: Open PuTTY.

trans-unit.source: In Category, click Session.
trans-unit.target: In Category, click Session.

trans-unit.source: From the Basic options for your PuTTY session screen, enter the SSH address of your HDInsight server in the Host Name (or IP address) field.
trans-unit.target: From the Basic options for your PuTTY session screen, enter the SSH address of your HDInsight server in the Host Name (or IP address) field.

trans-unit.source: The SSH address is your cluster name, followed by-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: The SSH address is your cluster name, followed by-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: For example, myhdinsightcluster-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: For example, myhdinsightcluster-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connect to an HDInsight cluster on Linux using PuTTY</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connect to an HDInsight cluster on Linux using PuTTY</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To save the connection information for future use, enter a name for this connection under Saved Sessions, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: To save the connection information for future use, enter a name for this connection under Saved Sessions, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: The connection will be added to the list of saved sessions.
trans-unit.target: The connection will be added to the list of saved sessions.

trans-unit.source: Click Open to connect to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Click Open to connect to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: When prompted for the user name, enter hdiuser.
trans-unit.target: When prompted for the user name, enter hdiuser.

trans-unit.source: For the password, enter the password you specified while provisioning the cluster.
trans-unit.target: For the password, enter the password you specified while provisioning the cluster.

trans-unit.source: After you are successfully connected, the prompt will change to the following:
trans-unit.target: After you are successfully connected, the prompt will change to the following:

trans-unit.source: To run a Hive job
trans-unit.target: To run a Hive job

trans-unit.source: Once you are connected to the cluster via SSH, use the following commands to run a Hive query.
trans-unit.target: Once you are connected to the cluster via SSH, use the following commands to run a Hive query.

trans-unit.source: Start the Hive command-line interface (CLI) by using the following command at the prompt:
trans-unit.target: Start the Hive command-line interface (CLI) by using the following command at the prompt:

trans-unit.source: Using the CLI, enter the following statements to create a new table named log4jLogs by using the sample data already available on the cluster:
trans-unit.target: Using the CLI, enter the following statements to create a new table named log4jLogs by using the sample data already available on the cluster:

trans-unit.source: These statements perform the following actions:
trans-unit.target: These statements perform the following actions:

trans-unit.source: DROP TABLE - Deletes the table and the data file, in case the table already exists.
trans-unit.target: DROP TABLE - Deletes the table and the data file, in case the table already exists.

trans-unit.source: CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE - Creates a new "external" table in Hive.
trans-unit.target: CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE - Creates a new "external" table in Hive.

trans-unit.source: External tables store only the table definition in Hive; the data is left in the original location.
trans-unit.target: External tables store only the table definition in Hive; the data is left in the original location.

trans-unit.source: ROW FORMAT - Tells Hive how the data is formatted.
trans-unit.target: ROW FORMAT - Tells Hive how the data is formatted.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the fields in each log are separated by a space.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the fields in each log are separated by a space.

trans-unit.source: STORED AS TEXTFILE LOCATION - Tells Hive where the data is stored (the example/data directory), and that it is stored as text.
trans-unit.target: STORED AS TEXTFILE LOCATION - Tells Hive where the data is stored (the example/data directory), and that it is stored as text.

trans-unit.source: SELECT - Selects a count of all rows where column t4 contains the value [ERROR].
trans-unit.target: SELECT - Selects a count of all rows where column t4 contains the value [ERROR].

trans-unit.source: External tables should be used when you expect the underlying data to be updated by an external source, such as an automated data upload process, or by another MapReduce operation, but you always want Hive queries to use the latest data.
trans-unit.target: External tables should be used when you expect the underlying data to be updated by an external source, such as an automated data upload process, or by another MapReduce operation, but you always want Hive queries to use the latest data.

trans-unit.source: Dropping an external table does not delete the data, only the table definition.
trans-unit.target: Dropping an external table does not delete the data, only the table definition.

trans-unit.source: This returns the following output:
trans-unit.target: This returns the following output:

trans-unit.source: Query ID = hdiuser_20150116000202_cceb9c6b-4356-4931-b9a7-2c373ebba493
trans-unit.target: Query ID = hdiuser_20150116000202_cceb9c6b-4356-4931-b9a7-2c373ebba493

trans-unit.source: Total jobs = 1
trans-unit.target: Total jobs = 1

trans-unit.source: Launching Job 1 out of 1
trans-unit.target: Launching Job 1 out of 1

trans-unit.source: Number of reduce tasks not specified.
trans-unit.target: Number of reduce tasks not specified.

trans-unit.source: Estimated from input data size: 1
trans-unit.target: Estimated from input data size: 1

trans-unit.source: In order to change the average load for a reducer (in bytes):
trans-unit.target: In order to change the average load for a reducer (in bytes):

trans-unit.source: set hive.exec.reducers.bytes.per.reducer=<html></html>
trans-unit.target: set hive.exec.reducers.bytes.per.reducer=<html></html>

trans-unit.source: In order to limit the maximum number of reducers:
trans-unit.target: In order to limit the maximum number of reducers:

trans-unit.source: set hive.exec.reducers.max=<html></html>
trans-unit.target: set hive.exec.reducers.max=<html></html>

trans-unit.source: In order to set a constant number of reducers:
trans-unit.target: In order to set a constant number of reducers:

trans-unit.source: set mapreduce.job.reduces=<html></html>
trans-unit.target: set mapreduce.job.reduces=<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Starting Job = job_1421200049012_0006, Tracking URL = <html></html>:8088/proxy/application_1421200049012_0006/
trans-unit.target: Starting Job = job_1421200049012_0006, Tracking URL = <html></html>:8088/proxy/application_1421200049012_0006/

trans-unit.source: Kill Command = /usr/hdp/2.2.1.0-2165/hadoop/bin/hadoop job -kill job_1421200049012_0006
trans-unit.target: Kill Command = /usr/hdp/2.2.1.0-2165/hadoop/bin/hadoop job -kill job_1421200049012_0006

trans-unit.source: Hadoop job information for Stage-1: number of mappers: 1; number of reducers: 1
trans-unit.target: Hadoop job information for Stage-1: number of mappers: 1; number of reducers: 1

trans-unit.target: 2015-01-16 00:02:55,488 Stage-1 map = 100%, reduce = 0%, Cumulative CPU 3.32 sec

trans-unit.target: 2015-01-16 00:03:05,298 Stage-1 map = 100%, reduce = 100%, Cumulative CPU 5.62 sec

trans-unit.target: MapReduce Total cumulative CPU time: 5 seconds 620 msec

trans-unit.target: MapReduce Jobs Launched:

trans-unit.target: Stage-Stage-1: Map: 1 Reduce: 1 Cumulative CPU: 5.62 sec HDFS Read: 0 HDFS Write: 0 SUCCESS

trans-unit.target: Total MapReduce CPU Time Spent: 5 seconds 620 msec

trans-unit.source: OK
trans-unit.target: OK

trans-unit.source: [ERROR] 3
trans-unit.target: [ERROR] 3

trans-unit.target: Time taken: 60.991 seconds, Fetched: 1 row(s)

trans-unit.source: Note that the output contains [ERROR] 3, as there are three rows that contain this value.
trans-unit.target: Note that the output contains [ERROR] 3, as there are three rows that contain this value.

trans-unit.source: Use the following statements to create a new "internal" table named errorLogs:
trans-unit.target: Use the following statements to create a new "internal" table named errorLogs:

trans-unit.source: These statements perform the following actions:
trans-unit.target: These statements perform the following actions:

trans-unit.source: CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS - Creates a table, if it does not already exist.
trans-unit.target: CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS - Creates a table, if it does not already exist.

trans-unit.source: Since the EXTERNAL keyword is not used, this is an internal table, which is stored in the Hive data warehouse and is managed completely by Hive.
trans-unit.target: Since the EXTERNAL keyword is not used, this is an internal table, which is stored in the Hive data warehouse and is managed completely by Hive.

trans-unit.source: Unlike external tables, dropping an internal table will delete the underlying data as well.
trans-unit.target: Unlike external tables, dropping an internal table will delete the underlying data as well.

trans-unit.source: STORED AS ORC - Stores the data in Optimized Row Columnar (ORC) format.
trans-unit.target: STORED AS ORC - Stores the data in Optimized Row Columnar (ORC) format.

trans-unit.source: This is a highly optimized and efficient format for storing Hive data.
trans-unit.target: This is a highly optimized and efficient format for storing Hive data.

trans-unit.source: INSERT OVERWRITE ... SELECT - Selects rows from the log4jLogs table that contain [ERROR], and then inserts the data into the errorLogs table.
trans-unit.target: INSERT OVERWRITE ... SELECT - Selects rows from the log4jLogs table that contain [ERROR], and then inserts the data into the errorLogs table.

trans-unit.source: To verify that only rows containing [ERROR] in column t4 were stored to the errorLogs table, use the following statement to return all the rows from errorLogs:
trans-unit.target: To verify that only rows containing [ERROR] in column t4 were stored to the errorLogs table, use the following statement to return all the rows from errorLogs:

trans-unit.source: The following output should be displayed on the console:
trans-unit.target: The following output should be displayed on the console:

trans-unit.source: The returned data should all correspond to [ERROR] logs.
trans-unit.target: The returned data should all correspond to [ERROR] logs.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: In this Linux tutorial, you have learned how to provision a Hadoop cluster on Linux with HDInsight and run a Hive query on it by using SSH.
trans-unit.target: In this Linux tutorial, you have learned how to provision a Hadoop cluster on Linux with HDInsight and run a Hive query on it by using SSH.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see the following articles:
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see the following articles:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Manage HDInsight clusters using Ambari</linkText><title></title></link>: Linux-based HDInsight clusters use Ambari for management and monitoring of Hadoop services.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Manage HDInsight clusters using Ambari</linkText><title></title></link>: Linux-based HDInsight clusters use Ambari for management and monitoring of Hadoop services.

trans-unit.source: The Ambari web UI is available on each cluster at https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: The Ambari web UI is available on each cluster at https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: While many sections of the Ambari web are directly accessible through the Internet, the web UI for Hadoop services such as Resource Manager or Job History require the use of an SSH tunnel.
trans-unit.target: While many sections of the Ambari web are directly accessible through the Internet, the web UI for Hadoop services such as Resource Manager or Job History require the use of an SSH tunnel.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using an SSH tunnel with HDInsight, see the following articles:
trans-unit.target: For more information on using an SSH tunnel with HDInsight, see the following articles:

trans-unit.source: * <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: * <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: * <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: * <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight on Linux using custom options</linkText><title></title></link>: Learn more details about how to provision HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight on Linux using custom options</linkText><title></title></link>: Learn more details about how to provision HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: URLs for services hosted on the cluster, such as Ambari and WebHCat
